qas.question: What is the Greece Carnival also called?
What does the Opening of the Triodion derive from?

answers.text: the liturgical book used by the church

qas.question: What is one of the festival season's high points?
What types of dinners do people enjoy during the season's high point?
What do people engage in after they've disguised themselves?

context: In Greece Carnival is also known as <a0_0>the Apokriés<a0_0/> (Greek: Αποκριές, "saying goodbye to meat"), or the season of the "Opening of the Triodion", so named after <a1_0>the liturgical book used by the church<a1_0/> from then until Holy Week. One of the season's high points is <a2_0>Tsiknopempti<a2_0/>, when celebrants enjoy <a3_0>roast beef<a3_0/> dinners; the ritual is repeated the following Sunday. The following week, the last before Lent, is called Tyrinē (Greek: Τυρινή, "cheese [week]") because meat is forbidden, although dairy products are not. Lent begins on "Clean Monday", the day after "Cheese Sunday". Throughout the Carnival season, people disguise themselves as maskarádes ("masqueraders") and engage in <a4_0>pranks and revelry<a4_0/>.
